873faf8d-5504-490e-b9da-86269f2c196c.japanese: 始めまして。どうぞ宜しくお願いします。

a61075ae-be20-4706-bcd4-658d33ac55ca.japanese: どうもありがとうございます。

94ffa6c8-88c9-4679-ab7e-0d6cf514f1be.japanese: ありがとうございます。

1b56b829-cfb0-4583-938a-f3cf363b9eba.japanese: 日本語が（よく）話せません。

18de96ba-a23a-4728-a748-9026cfe2c834.english: Is there someone here who speaks English?
18de96ba-a23a-4728-a748-9026cfe2c834.japanese: 誰か英語が話せますか？

985b6514-23b9-4f65-ae74-40052f3adc27.japanese: ゆっくり話してください。

5c1db1fd-da10-49d3-8cf1-7af4f74bbc24.japanese: もう一度言ってください。

203335dc-cb4a-4991-8e4b-ebe424e43c14.japanese: 日本人ではありません。

b82aaa4c-14e2-4aa3-b420-e1247bf96eab.english: May I have a bottle of _____?

b560c1cc-d037-427b-8c0c-21629ba550e9.japanese: お皿を下げてください。

00513b39-ec7d-4608-8f36-e55f1d70114e.english: Do you have this in my size?

00513b39-ec7d-4608-8f36-e55f1d70114e.romaji: Watashi no saizu de arimasu ka?

156f56b6-07bb-4879-999c-331e28bd4626.japanese: そんなにお金を持っていません。

c17f6fa2-61cf-4a66-82cd-8dba038b0fc6.japanese: 海外へ発送出来ますか？

93dd4965-6065-4f5b-ba01-78f93974f51e.japanese: 朝鮮民主主義人民共和国
93dd4965-6065-4f5b-ba01-78f93974f51e.romaji: Chōsen Minsyu syugi Jinmin Kyouwa koku

5b4e4efe-6996-40a6-8436-443f418a6898.japanese: ボスニア・ヘルツェゴビナ

a76fa943-211d-4ed6-85d1-9bad139ef511.japanese: 医者を呼んでください。

1b6ce4bc-5cf7-4ea8-afa8-0dd7a4d62129.japanese: 電話を使わせていただけますか？

f3c00220-5af5-405d-806e-c31b1f4d3c64.japanese: 医者に見てもらいたいです。

5152ba3a-f8f3-48e8-b840-7f3efe4afeb7.english: Is there a doctor who can speak English?
5152ba3a-f8f3-48e8-b840-7f3efe4afeb7.japanese: 英語の出来る医者はいますか？
5152ba3a-f8f3-48e8-b840-7f3efe4afeb7.romaji: Eigo no dekiru isha wa imasu ka?

ebd41a92-8265-4b3c-8f9c-71c918d2f7ef.english: Please take me to a doctor.
ebd41a92-8265-4b3c-8f9c-71c918d2f7ef.japanese: 医者に連れていって下さい。

002ab388-b66f-450f-acd8-8f3b6f06586f.japanese: 妻・旦那・子供が病気です。

1e5d59a2-58ce-4f9a-bc7c-51adbb4dc06c.japanese: 救急車を呼んで下さい。

9e6ec21c-e71b-4c49-8394-23ac674b4823.english: I need to go to the emergency room.
9e6ec21c-e71b-4c49-8394-23ac674b4823.japanese: 救急室にいかなければなりません。

62e674cf-7b3f-47b2-8e4a-c2a1235332ba.english: How long will it take to get better?
62e674cf-7b3f-47b2-8e4a-c2a1235332ba.japanese: 治るのはどの位かかりますか？
62e674cf-7b3f-47b2-8e4a-c2a1235332ba.romaji: Naoru no wa dono kurai kakarimasu ka?

f5fb6760-1d36-4bfb-9f09-b259ff04c3cc.japanese: 私は ... アレルギーです。

ba23fcf9-c5ab-47fc-9603-8796bdbc500d.japanese: 味の素・グルタミン酸ナトリウム

9e411571-570a-4ccc-b879-4ed1bbd2763d.japanese: 何かを呑んでしまいました。

21d03672-e41d-46da-8670-15735da60ddb.japanese: 耳が良く聴こえません。

d6755ca9-0a04-4a59-9a93-69fa1bc82745.romaji: _____ yuki no densha/basu wa doko desu ka?

b9d1f5b0-cb7c-4400-9711-5985ffbea060.romaji: Kono densha/basu wa _____ ni tomarimasu ka?

57d2c475-9b22-4fbb-b556-980a57d48ece.japanese: _____ 行きの電車・バスは何時に出発しますか?
57d2c475-9b22-4fbb-b556-980a57d48ece.romaji: _____ yuki no densha/basu wa nanji ni shuppatsu shimasu ka?

89d3bdd9-c343-420b-8bb2-ef433c139f59.japanese: この電車・バスは何時に _____ に着きますか?
89d3bdd9-c343-420b-8bb2-ef433c139f59.romaji: Kono densha/basu wa nanji ni _____ ni tsukimasu ka?

55fdf75a-ade6-470e-bf09-f6be385be10b.english: Where are there a lot of ...
55fdf75a-ade6-470e-bf09-f6be385be10b.romaji: _____ga ooi tokoro wa doko desu ka?

52a9826e-0ea8-453b-9ffc-40c36b6e6466.english: Please show me on the map.

19b616dc-b713-43aa-a061-e34daaa75f7b.japanese: 右へ曲がってください。

a8459480-597f-43d0-a0d1-62b12c83c961.english: How much does it cost to get to _____?

edfb2894-1507-45a7-bbea-9c2de4fa439b.japanese: そこまでお願いします。

ac001654-7a2b-4ad4-8d47-7b5130068c33.japanese: トランクをあけてもらえますか？

f0c455f8-4d63-4799-8213-53aa9af8cb87.english: Do you have any rooms available?
f0c455f8-4d63-4799-8213-53aa9af8cb87.japanese: 空いてる部屋ありますか?

aec64342-1e3e-420d-9b3d-5857f8aa09c7.english: How much is a room for one person/two people?
aec64342-1e3e-420d-9b3d-5857f8aa09c7.japanese: 一人・二人用の部屋はいくらですか?
aec64342-1e3e-420d-9b3d-5857f8aa09c7.romaji: Hitori/futari-yō no heya wa ikura desu ka?

4af3df46-3e90-4753-a4b2-d101734f425a.romaji: Heya o mite mo ii desu ka?

20bad903-889c-40e8-88be-81c5c9fc98cb.japanese: もっと ... 部屋ありますか?

e26894fb-4d64-49ef-a19f-f0b9ebcd42db.english: Do you know another place to stay?
e26894fb-4d64-49ef-a19f-f0b9ebcd42db.japanese: 他の宿はご存知ですか?
e26894fb-4d64-49ef-a19f-f0b9ebcd42db.romaji: Hoka no yado wa gozonji desu ka?

9bf3cab1-551c-4620-8442-ae8a1b095801.japanese: 朝食・夕食は付きますか?

6522c934-337e-44aa-97e5-f112aa64047a.japanese: 朝食・夕食は何時ですか?

2596ce43-34f0-4357-97d3-8c72a88cf8f1.japanese: 部屋を掃除してください。

9d5be14c-f12f-45b0-80e5-f312851dd3c7.japanese: … はいらっしゃいますか？

c6ace9f9-2337-4ff0-a0a8-43377a056d0e.japanese: ちょっとお待ちください。

8e61d3c9-5514-44e2-ae90-76acf74df742.english: I will call you again later.
8e61d3c9-5514-44e2-ae90-76acf74df742.hiragana: あとでまたでんわします。

d968b198-7912-4d25-a891-58a5a3e746ba.japanese: 電話番号は何番ですか？

58835a0d-63c0-4af4-ab3d-e070cebc843d.japanese: ビール一杯・二杯下さい。

c3e81554-1832-4b4f-bc2f-bd24a34d2746.english: A glass of red/white wine, please.
c3e81554-1832-4b4f-bc2f-bd24a34d2746.japanese: 赤・白ワイン一杯下さい。

74202910-03cd-414f-8461-a4106a67fee2.japanese: みんなに同じものを一杯ずつください。

74202910-03cd-414f-8461-a4106a67fee2.romaji: Minna ni onaji mono o ippai zutsu kudasai.

93fa29b1-5358-4b14-981e-a8cb4171889e.japanese: どこへ連れて行くのですか？
93fa29b1-5358-4b14-981e-a8cb4171889e.romaji: Doko e tsurete ikuno desu ka?

59b10a76-7e38-4472-9aec-c9e9a981eec8.japanese: 私は逮捕されてるのですか？
59b10a76-7e38-4472-9aec-c9e9a981eec8.romaji: Watashi wa taiho sareteruno desu ka?

e404ef73-1a71-45bc-9201-a6d3e833241a.english: I want to meet with the ____ embassy.
e404ef73-1a71-45bc-9201-a6d3e833241a.japanese: ____ 大使館と会わせて下さい。

bd938ed1-da6e-4c6e-9f98-33af8713fa4c.english: I want to meet with a lawyer.
bd938ed1-da6e-4c6e-9f98-33af8713fa4c.japanese: 弁護士と会わせて下さい。

1da7af38-26b5-49ba-92c6-204b83858c18.english: Can it be settled with a fine?

2ff7e2c4-7a79-4078-8beb-91013ebec991.english: That's how it is, isn't it? (General agreement, especially old people can be heard going "sō desu ne" back and forth quite a few times.)

fb4b9dcb-6168-4a7a-b6fa-10518e1a8604.english: I have made you wait (terribly) long. (Used as an excuse after any amount of downtime, even just seconds. Often also used as a starter to get things going again.)

fb949440-b8d9-4efe-8c2b-fc88a5241315.english: It's been honorably tiresome. (To colleagues in the sense of "you gave it all, good work", but more generally at the end of almost any activity.)

77863592-4903-4f20-9138-b285d717eb5a.english: Give it your best! (Meant to be encouraging and motivating.)

fb2f953e-1fc0-45f0-8c59-79cfeca0eb0c.english: I will receive. (To yourself before starting to eat or when accepting something offered to you.)

e18bf692-1ddb-4dff-a271-5fb430a030e7.english: I will trouble you. / I will be impolite. (When entering your superiors room or an unfamiliar house, when trying to get someone's attention or generally when interrupting someone.)

b6353551-e07e-47e0-83f8-4672bc2a736c.english: I have troubled you. / Excuse my impoliteness. (When leaving your superiors room or an unfamiliar house or generally as "Sorry to have bothered you, carry on.")

263a3aeb-2916-4ec0-b130-1ed1df286287.english: It is alright. (For general reassurance. Used with "desu ka?" to inquire if something or somebody is alright.)

8d71f942-237a-4cf2-94b5-53cce872e9fa.english: Great! / Incredible! (Very popular amongst girls and greatly overused.)

28e2b9b3-b5e5-4100-a521-399f919eed71.english: Reallyyyyyyy~? (Almost a standard reaction to any kind of news. Can be lengthened indefinitely and is hence useful to stall for time when thinking about a real answer.)

f911a079-5db3-476d-b13a-4b5d2efb3f27.english: Lie! (Doesn't necessarily accuse one of lying, usually used in the sense of "Seriously?!")

f48b7352-63c8-44ef-9620-9c4f807328e3.japanese: アメリカ/オーストラリア/カナダドルは使えますか?

d0c2c869-82d0-464a-b56f-c22073b10624.japanese: イギリスポンドは使えますか？

2823a354-2b9e-47d5-acf6-a46722baab22.japanese: クレジットカードは使えますか？
2823a354-2b9e-47d5-acf6-a46722baab22.romaji: Kurejitto kaado (credit card) wa tsukaemasu ka?

e5a33c63-029b-418c-a591-6c402c4ce6c4.english: Can you change money for me?

d773226c-7dd0-496a-9ccc-5bdfe680de12.english: Where can I get money changed?
d773226c-7dd0-496a-9ccc-5bdfe680de12.japanese: お金はどこで両替できますか？
d773226c-7dd0-496a-9ccc-5bdfe680de12.romaji: Okane wa doko de ryōgae dekimasu ka?

b74a1f1b-3de3-49a9-9f4f-c1af39b6a9c6.english: Can you change a traveler's check for me?
b74a1f1b-3de3-49a9-9f4f-c1af39b6a9c6.japanese: トラベラーズチェックを両替できますか？
b74a1f1b-3de3-49a9-9f4f-c1af39b6a9c6.romaji: Torabarāsu chekku (traveler's check) wo ryōgae dekimasu ka?

3f0a5b71-82c6-4719-90c9-3087bdce0610.english: Where can I get a traveler's check changed?
3f0a5b71-82c6-4719-90c9-3087bdce0610.japanese: トラベラーズチェックはどこで両替できますか？
3f0a5b71-82c6-4719-90c9-3087bdce0610.romaji: Torabarāzu chekku (traveler's check) wa doko de ryōgae dekimasu ka?

c40fa136-72a4-4a77-b01d-aaec3969157e.japanese: 為替レートはいくらですか？
c40fa136-72a4-4a77-b01d-aaec3969157e.romaji: Kawase rēto wa ikura desu ka?

f1c14dad-b501-4c8f-8bd1-34e6f7dc1d3a.english: Where is an automatic teller machine (ATM)?
f1c14dad-b501-4c8f-8bd1-34e6f7dc1d3a.japanese: ATM はどこにありますか？

88941df9-799f-4595-948c-24d3ba510483.name: Problems
88941df9-799f-4595-948c-24d3ba510483.notes:
What part of "no" don't you understand?

The Japanese are famously reluctant to say the word "no", and in fact the language's closest equivalent, いいえ iie, is largely limited to denying compliments you have received. ("Your Japanese is excellent! "Iie, it is very bad!"). But there are numerous other ways of expressing "no", so here are a few to watch out for.

いいです。 結構です。
Ii desu. Kekkō desu.
"It's good/excellent." Used when you don't want more beer, don't want your bentō lunch microwaved, and generally are happy to keep things as they are. Accompany with teeth-sucking and handwaving to be sure to get your point across - both of these expressions may be interpreted as positive responses if you don't include enough nonverbal indications to the contrary.
ちょっと難しいです･･･
Chotto muzukashii desu...
Literally "it's a little difficult", but in practice "it's completely impossible." Often just abbreviated to sucking in air through teeth, saying "chotto" and looking pained. Take the hint.
申し訳ないですが･･･
Mōshiwakenai desuga...
"This is inexcusable but..." But no. Used by sales clerks and such to tell you that you cannot do or have something.
ダメです。
Dame desu.
"It's no good." Used by equals and superiors to tell you that you cannot do or have something. The Kansai equivalent is akan.
違います。
Chigaimasu.
"It is different." What they really mean is "you're wrong". The casual form chigau and the Kansai contraction chau are also much used.

c6c6b26c-c407-4de0-8720-67442b74065c.name: Numbers
c6c6b26c-c407-4de0-8720-67442b74065c.notes:
Numbers

While Arabic (Western) numerals are employed for most uses in Japan, you will occasionally still spot Japanese numerals at eg. markets and the menus of fancy restaurants. The characters used are nearly identical to Chinese numerals, and like Chinese, Japanese uses groups of 4 digits, not 3. "One million" is thus 百万 (hyaku-man), literally "hundred ten-thousands".

There are both Japanese and Chinese readings for most numbers, but presented below are the more commonly used Chinese readings. Note that, due to superstition (shi also means "death"), 4 and 7 typically use the Japanese readings yon and nana instead.

Counters

When counting objects, Japanese uses special counter words. For example, "two bottles of beer" is ビール２本 biiru nihon, where ni is "two" and -hon means "bottles". Unlike in English, where counter words are often optional or non-existent, in Japanese they're mandatory whenever you count something (e.g. 車２台 kuruma ni-dai, two cars; 台 dai counts machines).

Note how many counters change form depending on the previous number: one, two, three glasses are ippai, nihai, sanbai respectively.　There are also a few exceptions: one person and two people are hitori and futari. 20 years old is usually pronounced hatachi. You'll still be understood if you get these wrong though.

一つ hitotsu

For numbers from one to nine, an old counting system is often used which applies to virtually any object you may want to count, without the need to attach a specific counter:

  1. 一つ hitotsu
  2. 二つ futatsu
  3. 三つ mittsu
  4. 四つ yottsu
  5. 五つ itsutsu
  6. 六つ muttsu
  7. 七つ nanatsu
  8. 八つ yattsu
  9. 九つ kokonotsu

It is always a good idea to use a specific counter whenever possible, but using the generic numbers above is often equally acceptable. This system is rarely used anymore for numbers greater than nine.

be4745fe-a10c-49aa-935a-b9d8925bf811.name: Time
be4745fe-a10c-49aa-935a-b9d8925bf811.notes:
Clock Time

Clock times are formed as Chinese numeral plus 時 ji, for example, goji 5時 for five o'clock. The exception is four o'clock which is pronounced yoji (四時) instead of shiji. You will be understood if you simply substitute gozen 午前 for "AM" and gogo 午後 for PM, although other time qualifiers like 朝 asa for morning and 夜 yoru for night may be more natural. The 24-hour clock is also commonly used in official contexts such as train schedules. TV schedules occasionally use a modified 24-hour clock, with late night showtimes counted from the previous day, e.g. Monday at 26:00 indicates Tuesday at 2:00 AM.

Duration

Confusingly, the Japanese words for "N days" (long) and "Nth day" are the same, so eg. 二日 futsuka means both "two days" and "the second day of the month". You can tag on -間 kan at the end, eg. futsukakan 2日間, to clarify that you mean "two days long". The exception is 一日, which is read ichinichi to mean "one day/all day", but tsuitachi to mean "first day".

Writing Time and Date

Dates are written in year/month/day (day of week) format, with markers:

2007年3月21日(火)

Note that Imperial era years, based on the name and duration of the current Emperor's reign, are also frequently used. 2010 in the Gregorian calendar corresponds to Heisei 22 (平成22年), which may be abbreviated as "H22". Dates like "22/03/24" (March 24, Heisei 22) are also occasionally seen.

Interestingly, the era name doesn't necessarily change with the Gregorian calendar year, but instead on the death of the reigning Emperor. So the year 1989 is considered to be both Showa 64 and Heisei 1 - Showa up until Emperor Hirohito's death on 7 January, and Heisei from Emperor Akihito's ascension to the throne on 8 January.

e6a8e931-6b5a-4a0a-9af0-a3fa6831131e.name: Colors
e6a8e931-6b5a-4a0a-9af0-a3fa6831131e.notes:
Many of the English words for colors are widely used and understood by almost all Japanese. These are indicated after the slash.

Note that some Japanese colors are normally suffixed with -iro (色) to distinguish between the color and the object. For example, 茶 cha means "tea", but 茶色 chairo means "tea-color" → "brown".

fbe18548-e7bc-465c-93ec-25c2eb084a84.name: Eating
fbe18548-e7bc-465c-93ec-25c2eb084a84.notes:
What are they yelling at me?

Most Japanese restaurants show their appreciation for customers by loudly greeting them in unison. Expect to hear the following:

Irasshai! or Irasshaimase!
"Come on in!", said when a customer walks in. You're not expected to respond in any way, just take a seat.
Arigatō gozaimashita!
"Thank you very much!", said when a customer leaves.

If your meal was good, thank the chef or staff with Gochisōsama deshita when leaving, and you'll get an extra-hearty thank you in return!

f386d747-9189-41b8-925a-3bd7923eb1bf.name: Bars
f386d747-9189-41b8-925a-3bd7923eb1bf.notes:
Sake

Sake, known in Japanese as 日本酒 nihonshu, has a vocabulary all its own. Here is a brief introduction.

atsukan
熱燗 Heated sake. Recommended only in winter with cheap sake.
hiyashi, reishu
冷やし, 冷酒 Chilled sake. The way to drink better sake.
isshōbin
一升瓶 The standard sake bottle, containing 10 gō, ie. 1.8 liters.
ichigō
一合 The standard measure for servings of sake, around 180 milliliters.
tokkuri
徳利 A small ceramic jug used to pour sake, contains around one gō
masu
升 A square wooden box traditionally used to drink chilled sake, also contains one gō. Drink from the corner.
choko
ちょこ A tiny gulp-sized ceramic cup for sake.

80cf758a-5bbc-4ced-9e5c-845be86b2b32.name: Family
80cf758a-5bbc-4ced-9e5c-845be86b2b32.notes:
Family

In Japanese, it's always important to use less respectful terms for your own family and more respectful terms for another's family. Note also that the words for older/younger brother/sister are different.

4854b9cf-29f4-4293-a190-ce3dc463b291.name: Authority
4854b9cf-29f4-4293-a190-ce3dc463b291.notes:
Authority

In Japan, you can legally be incarcerated for twenty-three (23) days before you are charged, but you do have the right to see a lawyer after the first 48 hours of detention. Note that if you sign a confession, you will be convicted.

3c15175b-9c1d-4b67-a427-d5b02c232b9d.name: Typical Expressions
3c15175b-9c1d-4b67-a427-d5b02c232b9d.notes:
Four-Syllable Words

If words can be shortened, Japanese will inevitably shorten them. Two by two syllables is often the sweet spot, and sometimes it's hard to guess where those came from.

デジカメ deji kame
デジタルカメラ dejitaru kamera, a digital camera.
パソコン pasokon
パーソナルコンピューター pāsonaru konpyūtā, a personal computer. ノート nōto stands for notebooks.
プリクラ purikura
プリントクラブ purinto kurabu or "print club". A sort of extremely flashy photo booth and a favourite pastime for many.
パチスロ pachi suro
パチンコ＆スロット pachinko & surotto, locations everywhere offering the number one Japanese gambling game pachinko and traditional slot machines.
リモコン rimokon
リモートコントロール rimōto kontorōru, remote control
KY kei wai
空気読めない kūki yomenai, "can't read the air", meaning an unperceptive person who can't read between the lines/can't keep up with a conversation.
